questions.question: Question 1: Seronegative spondyloarthritides are associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Seronegative spondyloarthritides are associated with HLA-B27. 532 
Sold by @itachibot The spondyloarthritides are a group of overlapping disorders that share certain clinical features 
and genetic associations (HLA-B27). These disorders include: • Psoriatic arthritis • Ankylosing spondylitis • Reactive arthritis • Enteropathic arthritis • Juvenile onset spondyloarthritis • Undifferentiated spondyloarthritis Usually, rheumatoid factor (RF) assay is negative in spondyloarthritides. Hence, they are also 
referred to as seronegative arthritis.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 26-year-old man presented with pain and stiffness in his lower back. His X-ray spine is 
given below. Which of the following is true about his condition?

options.c: It is associated with HLA B47
options.d: Associated with low serum IgA levels

questions.explanation:
The given clinical features along with the classical bamboo-spine appearance on X-ray point 
towards a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis (AS). In ankylosing spondylitis, the symptoms 
improve with activity. Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is an inflammatory disorder that affects the axial skeleton primarily, 
and may also involve peripheral joints. It is strongly associated with HLA-B27. It usually presents 
in the mid-twenties. It presents with lower back pain that improves with activity and worsens with rest or inactivity. 
Early morning stiffness is a characteristic feature. It is associated with elevated serum IgA levels. 
NSAIDs are the first line of pharmacological therapy. It is also associated with extra-articular manifestations like uveitis, interstitial lung disease, aortic 
regurgitation, etc. NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.question:
Question 3: 526 
Sold by @itachibot What are the key cytokines involved in the pathogenesis of ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.explanation:
The key cytokines involved in the pathogenesis of ankylosing spondylitis are TNF- and IL-17. 
IL-23 also plays a role in pathogenesis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with Crohn's disease presents with back pain and stiffness. The physician suspects 
ankylosing spondylitis and orders an MRI for evaluation. Which of the following joints will be 
the earliest to be involved?
questions.explanation:
The earliest joint to be involved in ankylosing spondylitis is the sacroiliac joint. Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is an inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the axial skeleton. 
It is more common in males, usually presenting between 20-30 years of age. 533 
Sold by @itachibot Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and peripheral arthritis can occur as extra-intestinal manifestations of 
inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). They are more common in Crohn's disease than in ulcerative 
colitis.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 2ç-year-old male patient with low backache and early morning stiffness for the past 1 year 
is diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis. Which of the following is not associated with the 
haplotype related to this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ankylosing spondylitis is related to the HLA-B27 haplotype. This haplotype is not associated with 
Behcet's disease. It is associated with HLA B51. Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that mainly affects the spine and 
sacroiliac joint. Individuals who inherit this class I HLA allele (HLA-B27) have a 100–200 fold 
greater chance (odds ratio or relative risk) of developing the disease compared with those who do 
not carry HLA-B27. Many autoimmune diseases are associated with different class II HLA alleles.

questions.question:
Question 6: The following test is performed in a patient to evaluate back pain associated with stiffness. 
Identify the test. 527 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The test performed is modified Schober’s test. This test is done in patients with 
suspected ankylosing spondylitis. It is used to detect reduced flexion of the spine. The test involves marking two points- at the 
lumbosacral junction and 10 cm above it. The patient is then asked to bend forward with knees 
fully extended and the distance between the two points is measured. This distance normally increases by 2 cm. An increase of <2 cm indicates reduced flexion. In the image given below the distance increases by 5cm which is normal. Option A: Gaenslen's test is used to detect primary chronic inflammation of the sacroiliac joint. Option B: Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. 534 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Adam's forward bending test is performed on a patient to differentiate structural from 
non-structural scoliosis.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which is the most common extra-articular manifestation seen in patients diagnosed with 
ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.explanation:
The most common extraarticular manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is anterior uveitis. It usually presents with unilateral pain, photophobia and increased lacrimation. It is also 
associated with other spondyloarthritides like reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis and 
enteropathic arthritis. Other extra-articular manifestations of AS include: • GIT: ileitis, colitis, inflammatory bowel disease • Cardiovascular: increased risk of IHD, aortic insufficiency, heart block • Respiratory: upper lobe fibrosis • Neurological: cauda equina syndrome • Skin: acne fulminans, hidradenitis suppurativa

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following conditions predominantly involve the upper lobe of the lung?
questions.explanation:
Ankylosing spondylitis predominantly involves the upper lobe of the lung leading to pulmonary 
fibrosis. Rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, and asbestosis predominantly involve the lower lobes of the 
lungs.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient who presented with chronic lower back pain has been diagnosed with ankylosing 
spondylitis. What is the first line of pharmacological therapy?
questions.explanation:
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first line of pharmacological therapy for 
ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Management of ankylosing spondylitis includes: • First-line management: • Physiotherapy to maintain posture and range of motion. • NSAIDs- reduce pain and tenderness, increase mobility, and slow down the disease progression. • TNF  inhibitors- in patients who do not respond to NSAID therapy. It is not used in all patients 
because of side effects like reactivation of TB, hypersensitivity reactions, pancytopenia, 
drug-induced psoriasis, etc. • Anti-IL-17 antibodies- in patients with failed anti-TNF therapy. • Surgery- improves mobility in patients with severe arthritis and joint stiffness. 535 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 27-year-old man with ankylosing spondylitis is not responding to standard therapy. His 
physician decides to prescribe him an anti-IL-17 monoclonal antibody. Which of the following 
drugs would he prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Secukinumab is an anti-IL-17 monoclonal antibody used in patients with ankylosing spondylitis 
who are not responding to NSAIDs and anti-TNF therapy. Management of ankylosing spondylitis includes: • First-line management: • Physiotherapy to maintain posture and range of motion. • NSAIDs- reduce pain and tenderness, increase mobility, and slow down the disease progression. • TNF  inhibitors- in patients who do not respond to NSAID therapy. It is not used in all patients 
because of side effects like reactivation of TB, hypersensitivity reactions, pancytopenia, 
drug-induced psoriasis, etc. • Anti-IL-17 antibodies- in patients with failed anti-TNF therapy. • Surgery- improves mobility in patients with severe arthritis and joint stiffness. Option A: Ustekinumab is an anti-IL-12/23 monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of 
psoriasis. Options C and D: Infliximab and adalimumab are anti-TNF- monoclonal antibodies used in the 
treatment of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 15-year-old boy presents with generalized malaise and painful swelling of his right knee 
joint since 10 days. He also complains of pain and discomfort during urination. He was 
treated for diarrhea last month. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario describes an acute arthritis following an infection which is also associated with 
urethritis and generalized malaise. These features are suggestive of reactive arthritis. Reactive arthritis also known as Reiter's syndrome is a seronegative spondyloarthritis that occurs 
as a consequence of a recent enteric or urogenital infection. It is associated with HLA B27. It is 
also associated with extra-articular manifestations such as: • Urogenital- urethritis, prostatitis, cervicitis • Ocular- conjuctivitis, anterior uveitis • Mucocutaneous- oral ulcers, keratoderma blennorrhagica, circinate balanitis In some patients it presents as a triad of: • Arthritis • Urethritis • Conjunctivitis

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient presents with painful knee swelling, dysuria, and conjunctivitis. Which of the 
following infectious agents is least likely to cause this?
questions.explanation:
536 
Sold by @itachibot The given scenario of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of reactive arthritis. It is 
not caused by Neisseria gonorrhea. Disseminated gonococcal infection causes gonococcal arthritis. It comprises localized septic 
arthritis and arthritis-dermatitis syndrome. Reactive arthritis is usually caused due to LPS (lipopolysaccharide) component of the 
gram-negative organisms or cross-reactivity with synovial antigens. The common causative 
organisms include: • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common) • Salmonella • Shigella • Yersinia • Campylobacter

questions.question:
Question 13: A middle-aged man presented with pain and swelling of his right knee for one week. It started 
progressing to the ankle joints and feet for the past 2 days. He gives a history of diarrhea and 
burning micturition 4 weeks ago. On examination, his soles showed the following lesions. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of acute arthritis following a recent infection and additive 
pattern (involvement of new joints within few days) and examination finding of keratoderma 
blennorrhagica (image) are suggestive of reactive arthritis. Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a mucocutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis. It presents 
as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions or crusting on the palms and soles. Other mucocutaneous manifestations of reactive arthritis include: • Oral ulcers - superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic • Circinate balanitis - consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the 
glans penis

Question 14: An elderly man presents with pain and deformity of his toes. The clinical findings are shown 
in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 530 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical image showing dactylitis, nail changes and telescoping of toes is suggestive of 
psoriatic arthritis. Clinical features of psoriatic arthritis include: • Psoriatic nail changes- yellowing and hypertrophy • Dactylitis- inflammation of the toes • Telescoping (shortening) of toes due to osteolysis • Severe deformity- suggestive of arthritis mutilans • Enthesitis- heel pain at the sites of ligament or tendon attachment Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints

Question 15: A 16-year-old girl is being evaluated for arthritis and uveitis. Which of the following would 
you not consider as a differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Juvenile onset spondyloarthritis (JSpA) would not be considered as a differential diagnosis as it 
has no associated extra-articular manifestations like uveitis, lung involvement, etc. It is a seronegative spondyloarthritis with onset between 7-16 years of age. It usually presents as 
asymmetric arthritis predominantly involving the lower extremities.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not a part of the SAPHO syndrome?
questions.explanation: Psoriasis is not a part of SAPHO syndrome. The SAPHO syndrome is characterized by: • Synovitis- arthritis • Acne- acne conglobata • Pustulosis- palmoplantar pustulosis, hidradenitis suppurativa • Hyperostosis- sternoclavicular and spinal hyperostosis • Osteitis- sterile osteomyelitis

questions.question: Question 17: Uveitis is an uncommon manifestation in patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Uveitis is a rare manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Ocular manifestation in RA includes 
scleritis, episcleritis, and keratoconjunctivitis. 538 
Sold by @itachibot Uveitis is a common ocular manifestation of seronegative arthritis e.g. Reiter's syndrome, 
ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA). 539 
Sold by @itachibot SLE and APS
